awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebraic Geometry and Singularities in Positive and Mixed Characteristic
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic Geometry studies algebraic varieties which are geometric objects defined by polynomial equations. One of the most natural problems in this area is to understand the singularities that naturally occur when considering algebraic varieties and how these singularities influence the global geometry of algebraic varieties. In recent years there have been a number of breakthroughs, especially in the case where we consider solutions over the complex numbers. At the same time new techniques and approaches have emerged for studying solutions in positive and mixed characteristics. The primary goal of this collaborative project is to advance and unify these ideas to further understand and solve some of the most challenging programs in both local and global algebraic geometry. In addition the project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.
 
The PIs will investigate singularities in positive and mixed characteristics by using a variety of techniques including those arising from the minimal model program, from the theory of F-singularities, and from Scholze's work on perfectoid algebras and spaces. The PIs will also organize workshops, a summer school and a conference, aimed at training young researchers in this area, disseminating recent results and facilitating further advances and breakthroughs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This projects focuses on singularities. Singularities are points in a space where the local geometry is different than the generic behavior of that space. For instance, if a plane is folded as a newspaper, then the local geometry of the folded plane near the crease is different than elsewhere. The crease consists of the singular points of the plane. More advanced versions of singularities include for example black holes. In particular, studying singularities is important with respect to theoretical physics.

In this project the PI and his collaborators proved several significant results. One direction of the investigation, which includes two separate projects with János Kollár, the PI and Kollár prove results that show that an important class of singularities that plays a central role in understanding deformations of high dimensional spaces can be recognized from partial information. These results have a high impact on our understanding of deformations, which in turn play a major role in our understanding of all spaces.

In a separate project, joint with Behrouz Taji, the PI proved several results that extend the applicability of analytic tools for singular spaces. These are significant, because originally while analysis is a powerful tool, it does not handle singularities well. In other words, the usefulness of the results of this project is that they extend the arena in which these analytic tools can be applied. The results of this project have been published in three separate articles.

This project also provided training opportunities for graduate students. During this project the PI worked with 10 graduate students. Five of these have graduated while the project was active and five are continuing to work with the PI. Even though the grant has now ended, these students continue working on problems related to singularities and deformations.
